Award.AwardTitle: Structural Evolution Through the Lifecycle of Hurricane Sandy (2012)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hurricane Sandy (2012) wrought devastating impacts on tens of millions of U.S. citizens. Protection of the lives and property of residents along the path of such a system is imperative; this requires understanding the physics underlying the system and being equipped to act on that knowledge. Development of physical understanding of the evolution of Sandy provides the knowledge to underpin future forecasts of similar systems and appropriate societal responses to those events. Analysis of the sensitivity of the observed Sandy lifecycle to the characteristics of the various contributing systems and environmental factors helps to constrain and refine this understanding. Methodologies employed here will be cluster analysis of the ensemble forecasts and related sensitivity simulations.

Intellectual Merit:
This research centers on a detailed analysis of the evolution of Hurricane Sandy (2012) through its lifecycle and landfall, and on exploiting ensemble forecasts to explore the realistic range of alternative lifecycles that could have eventuated. It is hypothesized that Hurricane Sandy underwent a warm seclusion near landfall, resulting in an atypical distribution of significant weather over the US northeast. The relative roles of Hurricane Sandy, the blocking high and upstream trough, the remnant Tropical Storm Tony, as well as surface fluxes and friction will be examined and the ensemble diagnostics and sensitivity simulations will be conducted. Point clustering will be used to evaluate the model skill in simulating the structural evolution of Sandy. Path clustering provides sub-groups from the ensembles whose evolution is similar over the entire forecast period. Analyses of alternative storm evolutions within objectively-derived subgroups of the ensemble members provide insight into the relative importance of different storm and environment characteristics. These can be further tested through sensitivity studies using the Weather and Research Forecasting (WRF) model.

Broader Impacts:
Elucidating the processes leading to the evolution of Sandy will have broad impacts in the theoretical understanding of these systems, in forecasting sphere, and in societal resilience planning.

The professional development of students at all levels will have broader impacts. The PI's role as co-chair of the WMO IWTC-VIII will have broader impacts through enhanced international forecaster/researcher communications, improving community understanding of tropical cyclones.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Very active hurricane seasons over the past decades have led to repeated devastation in the US, and almost all of the other countries in the North Atlantic. Our focus is on understanding how hurricanes impacting the US, Canada and Europe behave through their lifetimes. We use many different ways of looking at this problem: (1) We have used the best computer models for hurricanes to understand how weather systems over western Africa grow, maybe even into hurricanes; (2) We have used the newest data to develop a new picture of the ocean and atmosphere near the surface under the hurricane. This is where the hurricane gets all of its energy, so is important for understanding how strong the winds can get in a particular hurricane; (3) After learning more about the hurricane boundary layer, we looked back at the theory for calculating the maximum possible winds in a hurricane. Using our new results, we were able to improve on this theory. Our new results suggest that the winds in a particular hurricane could be even stronger than the old theory predicts, provided other features in the atmosphere don’t hold it back; (4) Hurricane Sandy (2012) devastated 24 states in the US, from the Southeast, Mid-Atlantic and New England, to Appalachia and the Midwest. We used hurricane computer models to learn why Hurricane Sandy took the track it did, and how it grew to have the wind and rain/snow that were so devastating. We learned how very small changes in Hurricane Sandy when it was near Cuba could have made a very different storm; (5) We used new, exciting statistical methods to create new ways of looking at hurricane forecasts. We think that, if hurricane forecasters used our technique, it would help them decide how likely a hurricane was to become a devastating storm, or one we can easily weather; (6) Storms forming just outside the Tropics can also turn into hurricanes. My group worked with colleagues in Spain to look at how these “Subtropical Cyclones” can affect Spain and Portugal; (7) One storm like this is Hurricane Alex (2016). We have begun to study Alex using similar methods to our study of Hurricane Sandy; (8) Finally, we have used other new statistical methods to try to explain how the very strong winds of a hurricane change, and how features in the atmosphere and ocean affect these changes.

Broader Impacts

Our research increases understanding of how hurricanes and storms that can become hurricanes grow. We care about how their strong winds and heavy rains evolve – since these directly affect people in their path – and also finding new methods for improving hurricane forecasts – since reliable forecasts can help people decide to get out of the way of an approaching hurricane. We have performed this research in many different ways so we can be sure that our results are valuable for society.

The men and women of my group are a diverse bunch, coming from Florida, Minnesota, Turks & Caicos Islands, Puerto Rico and Sri Lanka, with collaborators from Spain, Italy, Brazil and Germany. This grant has supported research contributing to three Masters degrees and two PhDs, as well as our work with two international graduate students. All of these scientists have successfully advanced to the next stage of their career in science.

My group is very active in communicating our science. Everyone in the group must learn to explain their science carefully and in an entertaining way to anyone who is interested, not just to other scientists. We use the traditional approaches of publishing our science in major journals (11) and presenting our research in invited talks and conferences (25). Our website is used by private citizens, industry and people from government to look at the output of operational models that is relevant to hurricanes.

We also communicate our science to a wider audience in a variety of ways. I (Evans) led a university-wide initiative to improve faculty and graduate students’ communication of science. I was one of three scientists presenting at the “NSF Superstorms” Capitol Hill briefing in March 2015. I have increasingly given interviews to the media on our science, as well as public lectures.

One of my (Evans) most fun projects is a collaboration with Mark Ballora, professor of music technology. We are interpreting hurricane data by setting it to music, a process known as “sonification.” Sonification is a precise mapping of the data, so you are hearing the same information and can interpret it as easily as if you were looking at a graph – but using your ears, instead of your eyes. Our goal is to study whether this new way of describing science using sound can make science more accessible to people who think that “science is hard.”
